title: Sliding blocks on an inclined plane

content.question:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Blocks of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2 lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are connected by a light string and placed on a frictionless inclined plane that makes an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with the horizontal, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> above. Another light string connecting the block of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to a hanging sphere of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> passes over a pulley of negligible mass and negligible friction. The entire system is initially at rest and in equilibrium.

(a) On the dots below that represent the block of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the sphere of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on each of the objects shown. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on and pointing away from the dot.

Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Blocks of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2 lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are connected by a light string and placed on a frictionless inclined plane that makes an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with the horizontal, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> above. Another light string connecting the block of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to a hanging sphere of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> passes over a pulley of negligible mass and negligible friction. The entire system is initially at rest and in equilibrium.

(a) On the dots below that represent the block of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the sphere of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on each of the objects shown. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on and pointing away from the dot.

(b) Derive expressions for the magnitude of each of the following. If you need to draw anything other than what you have shown in part (a) to assist in your solution, use the space below. Do NOT add anything to the figures in part (a).

i. The force <math alttext="uppercase T sub 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> exerted on the block of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by the string. Express your answers in terms of <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

ii. The mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which the system can remain in equilibrium. Express your answers in terms of <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , and physical constants, as appropriate.

(c) Now suppose that mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is large enough to descend and that the sphere reaches the floor before the blocks reach the pulley. Answer the following for the moment immediately after the sphere reaches the floor.

i. Does the tension <math alttext="uppercase T sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> increase, decrease to a nonzero value, decrease to zero, or stay the same?

____ Increase ____ Decrease to a nonzero value

____ Decrease to zero ____ Stay the same

ii. Is the velocity of the block of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> up the ramp, down the ramp, or zero?

_____ Up the ramp _____ Down the ramp _____ Zero

iii. Is the acceleration of the block of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> up the ramp, down the ramp, or zero?

_____ Up the ramp _____ Down the ramp _____ Zero

(d) Consider the initial setup in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></math>. Now suppose the surface of the incline is rough and the coefficient of static friction between the blocks and the inclined plane is <math alttext="mu sub s " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> . Derive an expression for the minimum possible value of <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that will keep the blocks from moving down the incline. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="mu sub s " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and fundamental constants, as appropriate.

(e) The string connecting block <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the sphere of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> then breaks, and the blocks begin to move from rest down the incline. The lower block starts a distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the bottom of the incline, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></math>. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the blocks and the inclined plane is <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> . Derive an expression for the speed of the blocks when the lower block reaches the bottom of the incline. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and fundamental constants, as appropriate.
